Posts.Content: Hi Debbie, I am so sorry about your breast cancer diagnosis. It blew me right out of the water too. I too, must face chemo and radiation. I had a node disection done on Tuesday for staging. The side effects of chemo are quite scary. But - not everyone gets side effects and many of them can be managed. Is there anything in particular that concerns you? If so, talk to your doctor and see if your doctor can link you up to other women who have been through it. If it wasn't manageable or effective treatment they would not be recommending it. Just think of the many many women out there who have beat it! We can too! Take good care of yourself, and let others do the same for you. Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo not sure

Posts.Content: Debbie and Claudia, The laughing is a good plan. I rent comedies. On your Christmas list should be things that are fun, funny and will make you laugh. Tell your friends to send you funny cards! Laughing actually has been proven to increase chemicals that help your immune system. Naturallly you feel sad, but limit the time you think about it. Treatment is temporary, (as my husband reminds me). "This is a temporary situation" - Crap to get through. You can do it. The best thing about the future is that it happens one day at a time. Keep us posted out here, ok Debbie? Thinking about you, Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo not sure

Posts.Content: Hi Debbie, I am so sorry you are going through this. Has your doctor tryed another medication for nausea? Zofran, Emend or Kytril? If one does not work, ask to try something else. Maybe Phenergan suppositiories - although they make you sleepy. Also pain medication. Sounds like you need it. I have not started the chemo yet. They just did my node disection on Tuesday and I don't know the results yet. They plan to use Adriamycin, (Doxorubicin) - I don't know if it is the same as yours, but it can cause enlargement of the heart, which they first get a baseline heart scan, and will monitor this during your therapy. Cytoxan will be given along with it, then Taxotere with steriods. 4 1/2 months they tell me. You sound as pertified as I am. I am trying not the think about it a lot. Are you sleeping? Get something so that you are sleeping. Do you have extended family and other support people? Call on them. Debbie, It is too overwhelming to think about it all at once. They may provide some diversion. I try to think that 1. The chemo will be given gradually 2. I will be monitored closely 3. I will have a headset with music and try visual imagey 4. I will deal with things one day at a time. 5. Not everyone gets all the side effects but medical-legally they must paint the picture. 6. Many many woman have gone through this and are survivers. I plan to ask my doctor about the statistics of how many women do get certain side effects. The actual numbers may be reassurring, I am hoping anyway. If anyone else out there has any other suggestions for us, please advise. Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo not sure

Posts.Content: Hi Sherlaud,  I had an axillary dissection 12-2-08 and I have numbness in my upper arm, from my shoulder to elbow,  breast, chest wall and left hand.  I also have a lot of pain in my upper back, kind of a prickly numbness.  At first it felt like someone had stapled my arm on.  I can't move my arm well due to nerve damage.  I had occult, (they could not find it or it went away by itself)  breast cancer with three positive lymph nodes.  I had chemo and radiation.  It got worse after the radiation.  They recently did an MRI and found a rotator cuff tear in my shoulder.  So I will start back in physical therapy soon.  I listen to relaxation tapes and take pain pills.  I think about 50% of the numbness improved after a about a year.  I still think it is healing.  When I listen to the tapes I relax my arm and I feel sharp shooting pains.  I think it is the nerves slowly coming back.  Love and Hugs, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Does the numbness under the arm, etc., go away????

Posts.Content: DEAR CAROLYN, I too, had a negative mammogram, (The research indicates that digital mammogram was more sensitive for dense breasts) so even though my health plan did not pay, I saw an out of plan physican each year and had a breast exam and digital mammogram. Then I would have my GYN exam and another breast exam at the six month interval. I have had multiple breast cysts and aspirations, as well as bipsies - negative for cancer. I thought I was covered. I was wrong. The last mammogram 10/09 showed nothing in in breasts, but an enlarged lymph node in the axilliary. Sonogram, even breast MRI showed - NOTHING! Axilliary node disection = 3 positive nodes. I am in chemo now. Plan on having a double mastectomy after - because how would anyone ever know if/when it relapses?? Then radiation. I already have lymphedema so I am very concerned with the radiation it will increase. Thank you for your story, you brave soul. Sharing gives us hope and more information to work with. I find many of the health care professionals very guarded in what they share with us. We are often the best ones - to share - we have been there!! ( Of course the medical info is always best to pass by them before we undertake any new treatments) Thanks agin BLess your heart Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: I started chemo 1-2-09 with Cytoxin and Taxotere for stage 2-3 infiltrating ductal breast cancer - no primary was found - 3 nodes postive. After two treatments, now my oncologist wants to add Adriamycin, siting a recent study, but only use Taxotere for the next two treatments, then 4 of Cytoxin and Adriamycin. I have had a real hard time with chemo, and never thought I would live through it and Adriamycin scares me to death. Please send comments and recommendations. My next chemo is Friday. Help! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Bless you all with all your stories.  I don't know if I can contribute to any knowledge here, but I will share my story. And I have always done everything right, by the way.  Never smoked, rare glass of wine, exercised, weight, normal, although about a year before my diagnosis went up to high, but still within my normal BMI.  I took estrogen replacement therapy and estrogen vaginal creams until my diagnosis at age 57.  Since I had a total hysterectomy and removal of my ovaries at age 29 I was on estrogen for a very long time, but a low dose. I took my estrogen with my grapefruit every morning and now they are finding that grapefruit tends to increase the strength of medications, (some of them).  Anyway in 2008, after having my breast exams done every 6 months, I was diagnosed with stage 2b local metatastic (3nodes) nothing in the breast.  Had a node disection, chemo, radiation and 5 years of Arimadex, then changed to Femora, and finally finished my five years with Aromisn?sp. due to all the aches and pains.   (All do the same thing.)  Now I am taking Evista.  I took 6 doses of Zometa because the chemo and Aromisin thinned my bones.  My diet, (I fight the urge to eat sweets) I have not had milk or milk products for about five years, little meat, mainly organic, increased by fruits and veggies, and do eat whole wheat, not a lot.  I am still here, so I must be doing something right.  They did find something in my hip last year and had another CT scan as follow-up and although it lights up on bone scans, CT scan showed it was about the same, a year later.  They tryed to biopsy it but it was deep in the hip and after a lot of drilling they did not get enought tissue to make a diagnosis. They gave me choice, one being an open hip biopsy, which sounded unreal to me, repeat the biopsy, and it will probably be the same, or follow for change.  I decided to follow with scans.  No invasive stuff.  I think you can have genes that "express" in different situations and cancer starts to invade.  I was in an extremely high stress job for 20 years.  The kind that you are responsible for EVERYTHING that goes wrong, but you have absolutely no control or no voice.  I think the stress was the tipping point.  I probably ate too much processed foods. too.  I have one cousin, out of 144, who had breast cancer at age 39.  History is vague on this, but she is alive and happy today at age 75!  Two of my grandmother's sisters had breast cancer, (later in life - 60's and 70's) and passed from it, as far as I can tell!  Anyway, that is my story and my thoughts, for everyone to see and get whatever they can from it!
Posts.Title: Are you Estrogen positive Breast cancer and think you know what caused it?

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, The sleeve worked, but I woke up with a huge hand! How do I find out about the massage? Is there a web site? How long does this take to resolve, if it is only intermittent? My husband found a machine online that is suppose to help a lot, but it costs $5000.00! Certainly if this is going to be a major issue for me I will get one. I just don't know. This is my first experience with it this bad. Are your arms normal size when it goes away, or is the effected one always a little bigger? Thanks so much for sharing. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, The sleeve worked, but I woke up with a huge hand! How do I find out about the massage? Is there a web site? How long does this take to resolve, if it is only intermittent? My husband found a machine online that is suppose to help a lot, but it costs $5000.00! Certainly if this is going to be a major issue for me I will get one. I just don't know. This is my first experience with it this bad. Are your arms normal size when it goes away, or is the effected one always a little bigger? Thanks so much for sharing. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Jo, Thank you so much for the information regarding the cardiac end of it with Adriamycin. That is reassuring. I get so much more information out of you all that have gone through it than the doctors. The doctors seem so "guarded" when taking to me, I don't know why. What kinds of effects did you have with your chemo? How many treatments did you have? God Bless you. You are the brave one! Love, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Hi Jo and Deb, Thanks to you both for your many words of encouragement. Yes, the sisterhood. It's a wonderful thing. Around my family I have been trying to stay strong and not "break down". A friend came with me for my MUGA scan. They could not use my port, just stuck me over and over, (what looked like veins had no blood), and well, I just lost it. I cryed long and hard and my friend held my hand the entire time. I guess I needed it. I am so emotional. I get a "get well" card or flowers and the flood gates open. I still feel I need to "hang tough" for my family. My parents are in their 80's and Mom was just diagnosed with eye cancer. My younger brother and sister both have many problems themselves with finances, and health. I feel I don't want to put anymore on them, so I fake it. I have 2 Taxotere treatments one tomorrow and in 3 weeks and then I start the AC. Once I start the AC it sounds from you both that it really hits you hard. I have had 2 infusions with Cytoxin and Taxatere and other than ending up in the hospital with Neuropenic fever, I have not had terrible effects. It sounds like they may start with the AC. I know, everyone is different, but those two together seem to really take their toll. I have a wonderful husband, Thank the Lord. Prayer helps. I have not been hungry, but I eat because I know I must. I have lost 15 lbs. I don't have that much more to lose. My doctors said most people gain weight on chemo. I don't think so. Sorry for my rambling. God Love Us All, Blessings and Love, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Jo, Thank you so much for your kind reply and encouraging words. I am so thrilled for you and I hope you have a wonderful celebration vacation!! Jo, I am still trying to hang in there, I know my anxiety is my worst enemy, and of course the side effects of the chemo. I have an itchy rash that comes and goes on various parts of my body. Mainly it's on my neck, chest, back, abdomen and head. It's like acne is some places and hives in other places. It fades on and off. I am on Doxycycline and Benadryl. They do help, but I must keep taking them. I have not had nausea and I have had a good appetite and I am eating well, I am holding my weight 126-129. After my five day hospitalization for neuropenic fever and rash, (after the first chemo) I had a port put in. I have been giving myself Neutogen injections after my second chemo and that has keep my white cells up. She wants to give me the AC and I am so worried about the heart effects of the A. How long and how many treatments did you have? Was your nausea controlled? Were you able to hold your weight? Thanks so much Jo, and again, CONGRAULATIONS! to you and your family Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: DEAR CAROLYN, I too, had a negative mammogram, (The research indicates that digital mammogram was more sensitive for dense breasts) so even though my health plan did not pay, I saw an out of plan physican each year and had a breast exam and digital mammogram. Then I would have my GYN exam and another breast exam at the six month interval. I have had multiple breast cysts and aspirations, as well as bipsies - negative for cancer. I thought I was covered. I was wrong. The last mammogram 10/09 showed nothing in in breasts, but an enlarged lymph node in the axilliary. Sonogram, even breast MRI showed - NOTHING! Axilliary node disection = 3 positive nodes. I am in chemo now. Plan on having a double mastectomy after - because how would anyone ever know if/when it relapses?? Then radiation. I already have lymphedema so I am very concerned with the radiation it will increase. Thank you for your story, you brave soul. Sharing gives us hope and more information to work with. I find many of the health care professionals very guarded in what they share with us. We are often the best ones - to share - we have been there!! ( Of course the medical info is always best to pass by them before we undertake any new treatments) Thanks agin BLess your heart Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in my Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Dear LizaMarie, I could have written what you did four years ago.  I was sure I would die in chemo.  I wasn't worried about the hair loss because mine was thin anyway and it gave me an excellent opportunity to wear wigs, which I still do even after my hair grew back, (why not take the opportunity to look --- WONDERFUL!).  I had 6 sessions, although after the third, they went to once a week, lower dose.  I can say - Xanax helps.  If ever there was a time in your life you needed some help with anxiety - this is it, but I have to say, the anxiety was the worst part of chemo.  I did not get sick, other than a few minor things. Once a little nausea, but they will give you a variety, (or they should) of medications to use for things.  You will get through this - remember - as my husband kept reminding me - "This is temporary" and "this too, shall pass." I started it on my 57th birthday!  Ya Whoo!!!  PS I am cancer free today.  I was stage 2 b with lymph node involvement and also had radiation.
Posts.Title: Petrified of getting chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you LizaMarie,  and you will be too! Love, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Petrified of getting chemo

Posts.Content: I had invasive ductal with lobular features stage 2b with no tumor in the breast, or anywhere else and 3 positive lymph nodes.  Breast cancer is so strange, so very different in different women. That was 4 years ago.  I had axilliary node desection, chemo, radiation and I am on Aromaisn, because the others gave me so much bone and muscle pain it was intolerable. It is still somewhat, but not as bad.   Estrogen pos, Hers- neg. Taking Zometa 4 mg IV every 6 mos for my bones.  Really would like to stop that.  I am waiting for results of my latest bone density. All I can say is you all are really brave. We are a tough crowd.  I have met amazing people on my journey.  I take life a day at a time and enjoy life to its fullest.  No one knows how long anyone has.  But,   . . . .there are millions of us!  We stand united!  And brave.  My hats off to you all. Bless you all!  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Petrified of getting chemo

Posts.Content: Hi All, you brave souls, I don't know who was talking about the funny taste in your mouth, but I eventually found that if I sucked on ice chips during chemo, it eliminated the problem of that metallic taste I got, just FYI.  Also, I don't remember who it was that had a reoccurance 22 years later, was it the same type of cancer?  If so, do you attribute anything in particular to your long remission?  Love you all.  Lets keep on sharing, and maybe someday, someway, well will figure this horrific desease out!  Blessing and Love,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Petrified of getting chemo

Posts.Content: Hello to the great sisterhood out there!  We are all in this together.  Is anyone taking Zometa IV every 6 mos for prevention of another breast cancer?  This is also used to prevent bone loss from the medications that are given that are antiestrogens. One of my oncologists highly recommends it, the other is dead set against it.  I have seen another at City of Hope, that is neutral. It does have some bad side effects, but rare. What do I do??? Would appreciate your comments! Love, Prayers and Hugs, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Zometa for Prevention of Reoccurrence

Posts.Content: Dear Leggos,  I am so sorry you are having to deal with this.  I know there are many more options, as far as drugs go, as I have a friend with metastastic cancer in another state and she has been doing well for years with metaststic cancer.  No pain, and goes about her day.  I am taking Arimidex also.  I have some stiffness with it, especially feet.  I wish you healing.  I, too, hated to take anything, even Tylenol for headache.  Now I feel "bring it all on" if needed, I will deal with the side effects.  Anything is better than cancer.  Where you on monthly Zometa?  Take Care.  Blessings,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Zometa for Prevention of Reoccurrence

Posts.Content: Dear Carolyn, Thank you for sharing your story with me. And congratulations! I am so happy you are doing so well now! It is so good to hear that there is light at the end of the tunnel! Blessings to you! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: I have had two treatments of Cytoxin and Taxatere for my stage III axilliary node breast cancer, although nothing found in the breast. I saw my Oncologist yesterday and she recommends starting Adriamycin, due to a recent international symposium in Texas on 12/08. She also extended my treatments to 8 unstead of 6. I am scarred to death of Adriamycin. Has someone had experience with this? I have had a real hard time in chemo, ending up in the hospital with neutropenic fever. I am giving myself Neutopen injections. Also I have a bad itchy rash I am taking antibiotics for. Please, help me. Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Change in Chemo Recommended

Posts.Content: Hi to all who have followed my posting about my tremedous fear of chemo. I had my first treatment yesterday. She got in first try and the Cytoxin was first, that was fine, Taxotere burnt, so she had to slow it down. The infusion took 4.5 hours. I was given Compazine 10 mg before the treatment and went home with that and Zofran, which I am taking around the clock for 3 days. This is my last day of Decadraon. I have noted some generalized puffiness, and flushing, - face and chest, especially in the areas that previous breast biopsies and the axillary node disection was. Otherwise I am feeling fine and drinking lots of water. One down, five to go. I realize it probably will hit me in a day or so, hopefully not too bad. Thanks to all, Blessing for the New Year, and I plan to continue to post. Still unsure whether I will to to radiation, or double mastectomies after chemo. Still consulting. Maybe both. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Survived My 1st Chemo Treatment!!

Posts.Content: Remember, most of the lumps go away and it's not likely to be cancer, so don't worry; but somethings you never want to ignore either! Good Luck and keep us posted! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Dear Jodysboys, Thank you so much for your continuing support. It really means a lot. This is the 3rd day post and I am having some kind of ear ache or sinus congestion. Every little ache, pain or symptom is so much more scary now. No fever, that;s good. I plan to call today and let them know. Thanks again Jodysboys
Posts.Title: Survived My 1st Chemo Treatment!!

Posts.Content: I would like to ask all of you who had negative mammograms, ultrasound and MRI's, and still had cancer, were your markers for cancer, CA 27, 29 or CA125 elevated?  I am three years out with invasive ductal breast cancer.  I still have both my breasts because they said I did not have breast cancer.  It presented in my lymph  nodes under my arm, so they removed 8 and three were positive for cancer.  So I had an axilliary node disscetion, chemo and radiation.  I am wondering what I should do for annual exams.  I am currently having my markers, ultrasound and digital mammogram.  My MRI was negative.  I hate to repeatedly have all the scanning/radiation exposure.  My doc's say that is enough. I am taking Aromasin and Zometa every 6 mos.   Please help.  I hate to expose myself to all that crap.  I feel fine, no lumps but very dense breasts.   Thank you.  Bless you all!
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: My mammogram showed an enlarged lymph node in my axilliary area. They took out 8 nodes. Three were positive for cancer. No tumor was found in my breast and my tumor markers and PET scans were all negative, except for the enlarged node. Pretty scary. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Thank you.  I am seeing my doctor today.  I guess if it is going to get you, there is really nothing anyone can do.  I knew a woman who went to ER with abdominal pain and bloating.  She had stage 4 breast cancer and her primary breast cancer was never found.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: It almost sounds like BC is a systemic disease, from the start, doesn't it?  I mean, does it really just affect your breast?  Or does it just "present" there as a sign that your entire body is being invaded?  Dr. Susan Love talks a lot about PREVENTION, something all the research money does not go to - the research money goes to screening methods and treatments.  I remember her saying that if your breast cancer is "invading" the neighborhood, then, after treatment of course, you need to "change the neighborhood"  How do you do that?  Read "The China Study"   It talks about all the high protein foods we are eating, the casin in the animal protein. Fuels cancer growth.  I have become a vegetarian, no dairy and started exersizing 30-40 minutes a day - to change the chemistry in my body. No, I am not sure it will be helpful, but there is surely enough prove out there that we are all eating crap, - not real wholesome foods.   So I figure it is worth a try.  It's my life.    So, again, I ask my question.   Has anyone had a cancer discovered that did not show up on mammogram, ultrasound or breast MRI and WHOSE CANCER MARKERS: CA 27, 29 AND CA 125 WHERE ALL NEGATIVE?  Thank you all  Prayers,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Hi Jodysboys, Thank you for your kind concern. I think my whole problem is anxiety. I am really doing fine otherwise. I am drinking lots of water and other fluids, no nausea, just fatigue and body aches, back pain, etc. I can deal with that. My pulse is so high and walking up my stairs makes it go even high and I get shortness of breathe. Saw the doctor yesterday, (just a primary care MD) to check my ears and they had found some blood in my urine, so I had that re-checked and it was ok and ears were fine. I worry from dawn until I finally fall asleep. It's funny that I don't worry so much about the cancer coming back as I do getting through chemo. Is that strange, or what?
Posts.Title: Survived My 1st Chemo Treatment!!

Posts.Content: On 4/23/2009 Lindalou wrote: Hello, I'm visiting from the Thyroid Cancer message board and have a question. Did any of you find a lump that did not show up on mammogram or ultrasound but turned out to be malignant? I found a pea size lump 2 weeks ago and went to my gyno. He also felt it and sent me for a diagnostic mammogram with ultrasound. The tech, AND the radiologist could feel it but could see nothing on the ultrasound. I was relieved at first but now I'm wondering if I should still worry. My thyroid cancer was found as a fluke so I'm a little skeptical. Any advise is appreciated! I have a breast clinical exam by my GYN and I private pay for another one every six mos because my HMO does not offer digital mammograms I have very dense fibrocytic breasts. I thought I would be safer with a digital mammogram, because they are computerized, they are more sensitive with dense breast tissue. In October, the breasts looked ok, but they found a enlarged node in my axillary. Ultrasound was negative and so was the breast MRI. I had an axilliary node disection with 3 positive nodes consistant with infiltrating ductal breast cancer - no breast tumor found. I am in chemo now and an trying to decide on mastectomies - bilateral before radiation. I would have someone biopsy that lump! My thoughts and prayers are with you. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: My mammogram showed an enlarged lymph node in my axilliary area. They took out 8 nodes. Three were positive for cancer. No tumor was found in my breast and my tumor markers and PET scans were all negative, except for the enlarged node. Pretty scary. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Thank you, but that was not my question.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Hi jcook,  I too, had the same in 12/08.  Could not feel the lump, just had enlarged node.  Nothing in the breasts.  I had chemo and radiation, 8 nodes removed, 3 positive.  Surviver too! going on four years!  I am also on anti estrogen medication and counting the days until I can stop.  Another two years.  Just hate it, but I am still here, and that's a good thing!  Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Hello all who are following me. Its been 1 wk since my first chemo and I had started to note pimples on my face, then around my head and neck and chest. I then noted they where all thoughout my head. They hurt! I saw the doctor and they put me on antibiotics. She said my WBC count was probably very low and I had a blood test. She said this is from the chemo. This is scary. This came on so fast! Has anyone else had this kind of reaction? She also said I was very close to losing my hair, already? Bonnie
Posts.Title: Severe acne 1 wk post chemo

Posts.Content: Dear Tre, Thank you for you reply and recommendations. I ended up in ER Saturday with a high fever and they thought I had a resistant staph infection, (MRSA) so I was hospitalized and placed on multiple IV antibiotics. My WBC count was only 800. They had problems with vein access, as I needed frequent blood tests and they only could use my right arm, (due to node dessection on my left), so they were using my feet also. It was terribly painful to have them attempting to find veins, so Wednesday, when the fever went down I was given a port-a-cath. Acne rash has cleared. They will not allow any vitamins or other supplements while on chemo. I am home now, very weakened. My next Chemo is next Friday.
Posts.Title: Severe acne 1 wk post chemo

Posts.Content: Please accept my deep sympathy for the loss of your beloved sister. Please, Please start attending a support group for those who have lost others. They are all over. You need to heal yourself. You will be honoring your sister. Love, Blessings and Prayers, Bonnie
Posts.Title: the battle lost...now what

Posts.Content: You and and Mom are in my thoughts and prayer. Keep fighting! Bonnie
Posts.Title: My Mother and the Alternatives That I am trying on her

Posts.Content: I share your concerns. I am still in chemo until June and I am using "Replens" a non-estrogen vaginal cream, but my chemo is giving me so much skin sensitivity that just the leaking out has given me a rash, so I have had to stop that also. You could have your doctor run a blood estrogen level to see if even a small amount of estrogent cream is making a difference. Unlikely. Have they told you about "estring"? It is a ring that you insert into the vagina and gives very low dose estrogen. It stays in place for 3 months. You should not be able to feel it, nor should he. Goggle it! Also you may try GENTLE vibration to increase the blood supply to that area. Good Luck, Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Topical Estrogen

Posts.Content: Bless you. I don't know if anyone really knows how or why cancer develops and why certain people appear to be more prone. I have done everything right as far as my health goes and when I had lymph node cancer under my arm in 2008 I was absolutely blown away.  I come from a family of people who live until their 90's and so I had planned on having good health until 100, at least, right?  I was 57 then. My husband and I read "The China Study" - Campbell It is a great book and I now I feel I understand more how the foods we eat can fuel cancer growth.  I stongly recommend it.  We are pretty much organic vegans now.  No, I don't know if it will work, but with your life; you only get one! Good Luck to you.  I have a friend who has had breast cancer three times, others, twice.  Hang in their and do your treatments.  All have made it through.  Count your many blessings and sometimes I like to just sit back and think.  "What is my life trying to tell me?"  Fighting upstream is devastating to ones health. Prayers,   Sandi  knowknow
Posts.Title: 4th time getting cancer in the lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Suzette, Thank you for your reply. Yes, my husband will be there some, but he does have to go into work after a while. I guess the infusion will take 3 hours and he will probably have to leave after the first hour, then will pick me up. The oncologist have taken me off all medications, including vitamins and mineral and sleeping pills, which means I am up all night long. I sleep in the morning until 10. I usually get 3-4 hours a night of sleep. It makes me so grunmpy. I know this is very hard on hi m. Sometimes I feel like a really whiny baby and I don't mean to. What can I do to help him get through this too? Thanks, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Hi Tre, Thanks for your recommendations. I am taking notes! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: I have recently been diagnosed with breast cancer and I will have surgery, chemo and radiation. I have an 18 1/2 year old cat who i dearly love and we enjoy her lap time with me brushing her at least once a day. Has anyone heard about restricting access to pets/cats during chemo? Is there anyway we can still enjoy this time with some restrictions, ( gloves, mask, etc?) Thanks, new to this entire ordeal.
Posts.Title: Chemo and contact with my cat.

Posts.Content: On 11/22/2008 apriljeff wrote: I asked my chem dr the same thing about my pets. No, you're fine and your cat will be also. He said only if you take radioacitve iodine for thyroid disease you can't handle pets or babies. Thanks so much! I had heard that when your white blod cells are very low, which chemo may cause, you are more prone to infections and pets have plenty of bacteria that could given me an infection that I may have to be hospitalized for. This is the most scariest thing I have ever had to face by far.
Posts.Title: Chemo and contact with my cat.

Posts.Content: HELP - I start chemo in 1 week - 1-2-09, I am 58. I will we getting Cytoxin and Taxatere every 3 weeks until mid May. Has anyone "been there, done that" that can help with encouragement, expecations? All I hear is "everybodies different, we can't tell you what to expect, we will give you medication for nausea and vomiting, you will be fatigued and you will be more prone to infections." What do you eat? - My tummy is in knots with fear, I've lost 10 lbs - and don't have that much to lose! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: DEAR NANA12, Thank you for your kind reply. The day is nearing fast. It is good to hear stories like yours. You have been through so much and made it! Good for you! I have the anti-nasuea medications and I will start the steriods, (decadron) tomorrow. I am really glad the day is almost here, as the anxiety is tearing me up. I am hoping I will get the right combination of anti-nausea medications and will relax into a routine after chemo starts. I don't have anything planned in the next 5 1/2 mos, just getting well again. Bless you Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Dear Jodysboys, Thanks so much for you kind reply and tips. I know you are right. It's that fear of the unknown. I really want to start ASAP. I am going to get a PIC line. Recommended by the oncologists. They said they will use Compazine and Zofran before treatment and Benadryl may also help with the nausea. I have not heard this about Benadryl. Yes, I do plan to get ready this week. Doing some things around the house and meal planning. Except, I don't know what I will be hungary for! The last oncologist I saw yesterday said that women usually gain 20 lbs on chemo - due to the Decadron, (steriod). Have you heard of this? Thanks so much, you have been a tremendous support. I will keep posting as able. Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: DEAR NANA12, Thank you for your kind reply. The day is nearing fast. It is good to hear stories like yours. You have been through so much and made it! Good for you! I have the anti-nasuea medications and I will start the steriods, (decadron) tomorrow. I am really glad the day is almost here, as the anxiety is tearing me up. I am hoping I will get the right combination of anti-nausea medications and will relax into a routine after chemo starts. I don't have anything planned in the next 5 1/2 mos, just getting well again. Bless you Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: On 3/6/2009 carolyn97222 wrote: I am at stage 3 also.  I would suggest that you to what my oncologist has told me to do.  My oncologist is at one of the top 100 hospitals in the US and he is fantastic.  He suggested I get my vitamin D level checked - the proper test for this is listed below.  Take a lot of D, calcium and magnesium, eat lots of veggies and fruits, etc.   If the cancer is  hormone positive, do not eat anything with soy in it and also no grapefruit at all.  Also, you should not take cohash or any kind of ginsing.   Here is a list of vitamins that it's important for you to take:      5-HTP  kills cancer cells    200mg      A - Beta-carotene 50,000 for 1 day then 25,000mg/day    B-6  - heart 2 mg   B-12  - liver, heart, hair, energy 100 mg   B-complex:  max 300 mg/day 50 mg x 3    Black cohosh  don't take  pain, cancer   C 5,000 - 10,000 mg in divided doses   Calcium - bones 3,000 IU   Chromium - â sugar, weight min 1000 mg   Co-Enzyme Q-10:  circulation/eyes 100 mg   D-3 - kills cancer; flu/cold -  I take 6,000mg up to 10,000mg day   E - circulation - â sugar, hair 1600 IU   Echinacea - immune system label   Grape Seed Extract - BP, antioxidant 100-200 mg         Iodine - can take Kelp instead 150 mg     L-Carnitine  - â fat, memory, weight 300 mg    L-Glutamine - â sugar, memory  ↓numbness/tingling   MSM - put in drink  label   Magnesium - energy, heart, eyes 1000 mg   Manganese - pancreas, cells 15 mg   Melatonin - antioxidant, night only  20 mg - kills cancer cells   Milk thistle - liver -  label - kills cancer cells   Multi-mineral & Multi-vitamin label   Potassium 20 mg   Selenium - antioxidant, slows symptoms 200 mcg   Zinc lozenges - immune, eyes 50 mg        turmeric, basil, cinnamon, thyme, saffron, and ginger - immune system               rosemary and basil for their anti-inflammatory power            Glutamine:  The standard dose is 10 grams, 3 times a day for 1 month after the trauma. Some companies add antioxidants and arginine to shorten healing time. If taken orally, glutamine powder can be mixed with water, juice, applesauce, or pudding. Some commercial supplement products contain glutamine in their protein mixture.The standard dose is 10 grams, 3 times a day for 1 month after the trauma. Some companies add antioxidants and arginine to shorten healing time. If taken orally, glutamine powder can be mixed with water, juice, applesauce, or pudding. Some commercial supplement products contain glutamine in their protein mixture.           After 1 month, reduce the dose to 5 milligrams, 3 times a day. 2 weeks later, reduce the dose again to 2 grams per day, 3 times a week. 2 weeks after that, discontinue completely.     The correct test is 25(OH)D, also called 25-hydroxyvitamin D Vieth found the literature published before 1997 clearly showed 10,000 units a day was unlikely to be toxic. Vitamin D toxicity probably starts around 20,000 units a day, and then only if taken for months or even years.  WOW, that is quite a list of supplements! How to you keep them straight or afford them all? How did you hear about all these? I have heard of a few of them. I was going to go to a registered dietian who specialty is breast cancer - all after my chemo. They told me I could take NOTHING while in chemo - just "eat a balanced diet". I try and load up on foods that are high in iron, but I keep getting more and more anemic. I am afraid I will end up needing blood transfusions before too long. Bonnie
Posts.Title: misdiagnosis?!?!?!

Posts.Content: Hi Nancy, Thank you so much for your prompt response. As you probably know, Christmas was very emotional for me this year. I am stage 3 also with 3 positive nodes, no primary found in the breast. This is a very rare form. I am trying to stay positive - any tips?. It is reassurring to hear your experience. I thank you and congratulations! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Hi Claudia, Thank you for your encouragement. How old were you when you went throught it? I did not think you could eat out when you are in chemo. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Dear Iccakes, Thanks so much for you kind tips! I do have some sea bands. Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Terrified of Chemo - HELP!

Posts.Content: Yes, you are not alone!   I was diagnosed in 11/08 with an "axillary node" presentation.  It was an enlarged node under my left arm found on a mammogram.  After a node desection it was found in three nodes and never in the breasts.  I got to keep my breasts and had chemo and radiation.  No symptoms and no one ever felt any lumps.  Hang in there.  This is a crazy time, so stressful.  Please let me know if you need anything further.  It will be six years in November and I am cancer free.  Blessings to you my dear.  You will get through this!  Bonnie
Posts.Title: breast cancer found only in lymphnode

Posts.Content: Hi Denise,  Yes, we are rare.  Mammogram showed enlarged axillia lymph node.  Turned out 3 out of 9 positive, no primary ever found in the breast.  After chemo and radiation I will be 6 years out from surgery 12-08.  It is a long road and rollar coaster, but you will get there!  God Bless you.  Let me know if I can be of any help to you sister!  Bonnie
Posts.Title: breast cancer found only in lymphnode

Posts.Content: Yes, I was on Arimidex for 5 years, now on Evista.  I just had a Breast MRI which showed a small "spot" on my sternum.  So then I had a bone scan, which showed my left hip has a potential problem and after the hip MRI, now they want to do a bone biopsy.  Merry Christmas, huh?                 Just breathe and enjoy every God given moment of health you get.  I think 10 years on Armidex is a good plan.  I had some aches with it, but I got through it.   Bless you my dear friend, Bonnie
Posts.Title: breast cancer found only in lymphnode

Posts.Content: This is so over-whelming to me. Could you give a sample menu for breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks? I was recently diagnosed and there is so much information about diet "out there" I don't want to lose any more weight before chemo. I am afriad to eat anything! Thank you for your kind recommendations.
Posts.Title: Nutrition-green tea, sugar

Posts.Content: Hi Claudia, It is so amazing to hear from someone without side effects from the chemo. You mean there is hope? You have really inspired me this afternoon, when I was at a low point. Thank you, Thank you , Thank you!!! I know that everyone reacts differently, but that is so good to hear. I was told you could not go out to eat due to the low white blood cell count and possible infection from food with baccteria - no salads, etc. I felt like I should plan to be on "shut down" only eating cooked vegetables through the nausea and vomiting. I am glad you are doing so well! Keep me posted! Love and Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: I have had my second chemo treatment, Cytoxin and Taxotere last Friday. Four more planned. I have had one issue after another, have been hospitalized, etc. and now I have more and more anemia with every blood test. I am taking Neuprgen injections for my low white blood cell count. I have always been more afraid of the chemo then the cancer, wondering how anyone ever makes it through. Since my doctors only tell me "everybodies different, we never know what to expect" there is little reassurance there. Has anyone out there needed blood transfusions with this type of chemo treament? I am considering stopping the chemo and just going on with double mastectomies and radiation. Thanks and Bless you All Bonnie
Posts.Title: Anemia on Chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you Deb I was at a low point yesterday. Trying to remain positive is difficult somedays. Hearing my pulse beating voilently and rapidly in my head after coming up a few steps or walking is very frightening. None of my doctors or nurses seem to think it is a big deal. Oh, well, I guess it all goes with the chemo. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Anemia on Chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks Janet, Yesterday I got even more bad news. My oncologist attended a symposium and now she recommends Adriamycin be added to the chemo, extending it another month. The cardiac damage and chance of leukemia scares me. Everything scares me. She also tells me that my chances are not as good as the previous oncologist had quoted. How does one live through all this? I have stage 3, no primary in the breast, low grade, + estrogen receptor, Hers/neg. Bless you, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Anemia on Chemo

Posts.Content: I have been diagnosed with breast cancer, even though all tests above where neg. Positive nodes, (Estr + receptor) no ovaries or uterus. Not sure what type. ALways had yearly mammos, ate right, washed the barbecue grill off before grilling, never smoked, rare glass of wine. Weight normal, probably could have exercised. more. Node desection will be done Tuesday for staging. So afraid of chemo, radiation and probably bilateral mastectomies, (how else can you monitor it's return, before it spread to other organs?) Has anyone else had any experience with this type of presentation of breast cancer? I need some reassurance.
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: Jodysboys, I hope everything went well after your chemo treatment. Just think, you will soon be done! I think I will be taking ADRIAMYCIN AND CYTOXIN FIRST, THEN TAXOTERE with steriods before the treatment. What did they give you for nausea? They gave me Zofran 8mg in the hospital after my surgery. No vomiting, but such intense nausea I could bearly drink. Then I heard that if you don't drink at least 3 quarts of fluids in a 24 hour period with the chemo your bladder may start to bleed. The whole ordeal seems so torturous to me. Were you in bed the entire days after treatment? Did you need someone to help you to the bathroom, bathe and fix food for you? How in the world to you get through this? Thank so much for your time and info. Bonnie
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Claudia, It is so amazing to hear from someone without side effects from the chemo. You mean there is hope? You have really inspired me this afternoon, when I was at a low point. Thank you, Thank you , Thank you!!! I know that everyone reacts differently, but that is so good to hear. I was told you could not go out to eat due to the low white blood cell count and possible infection from food with baccteria - no salads, etc. I felt like I should plan to be on "shut down" only eating cooked vegetables through the nausea and vomiting. I am glad you are doing so well! Keep me posted! Love and Blessings, Sandi
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: I have also very dense fibrocystic breasts, and thought I would be protected against high stage breast cancer because I had a clinical breast exam every 6 mos, examined my breasts weekly and had a digital mammogram, (which is the mammogram of choice for dense breasts) yearly. I have no breast cancer in my immediately family, distance aunt and cousin, but I have a huge family. I developed what they call axilliary node breast cancer. All tests, including the breast MRI were negative, but I was already stage III. It is undectable in my breasts and accounts for under 0.5% of all breast cancers I am told. It probably started in the tail of the breast, under the arm and went from there. Some luck, huh? Bonnie
Posts.Title: misdiagnosis?!?!?!

Posts.Content: Hello to the Sisterhood! I am the one that was terrified of chemo. Well, I have two more to go, so I think I'm going to make it. Very brutal five months. I have 3 positive nodes, no "detectable" breast tumor per mammogram, ultrasound or breast MRI. Estrogen +, Hers 2u - neg. The physicians I have seen recommend radiation - full breast, axilliary and super-clavicular. I was more comfortable with a double mastectomy and just axilliary and super -clavicular radiation, (they wouldn't do breast, if removed) They will do whatever I decide. Now I am re-thinking the double mastectomies. Has anyone else had to make such a difficult decision? Help! I would appreciate your coments. PS - My biggest worry is how to find future breast cancers if breasts are too dense nothing can find it before going to nodes again! Thanks, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Help Sisterhood! Radiation or Mastectomy?

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your sorry. Yes, we must persist - we know our own bodies! Your good judgement and persistance saved your life! Good for you! I am glad you are doing well! I may get there then?! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Help Sisterhood! Radiation or Mastectomy?

Posts.Content: Dear Jodysboys, I had the axillary disection yesterday. I will find out next week about the number of nodes involved. They always have to stick me many times before they can get a vein. Do you have a PIC line? Where is it? Does that mean they can draw all the blood and given you the chemo in that same vein all the time? Doesn't that burn that same vein out? How long can the line stay in before it has to be changed? Do they put it in surgery, or in the office? Sounds like a dream if it will last the entire length of chemo! I think about you too. You sound amazing, and so strong! Bonnie
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: Dear Jodysboys, Thank you so much for sharing your experiences and for your kind recommendations. You are a tropper! I admire you. I have to admit that even looking up things about cancer and chemo, radiation effects all are just to frightening for me right now. I know knowledge is power, but sometimes I don't even want it. I am just trying to take one baby step at a time. I am new to this site, but plan to keep you posted. You took a lot of time on your E-mail and I want you to know that I appreciate every word and second that you spent. I have copied it and I will keep it close at hand. Thanks again, Jodysboys May God Bless
Posts.Title: Mammo,Sono,Breast MRI - neg Positive Nodes

Posts.Content: Stacey, Thank you for for your kind reply. I already have lymphedema, which is another complication of radiation. I will probabyt chose mastectomies and radiation to the axillia and above the clavicle, as was recommended. One radiologist reccommended chest wall also, but I will pass on that because it could damage the lungs and possibly heart. A lot of their recommendations depend on type of cancer, markers, etc. How are you doing with the Zometa? Bonnie
Posts.Title: Help Sisterhood! Radiation or Mastectomy?

Posts.Content: Hello all,  I was the one terrified of chemo 1 year ago.  I had an axilliary node disection with three out of eight positive nodes, consistent with infiltriting ductal breast cancer.  I had three labs check the slides.  No breast cancer detected in my breasts.  I still have them. I have had chemo, Jan through May, 28 radiation treatments and except for some nerve damage and lack of range of motion and pain in my arm, axillia, and chest and back, I am really doing well.  I am so glad to be here.  The gift of life is awesome.  No detectable cancer with mammo and sono, but I am fighting my insurance for a breast MRI because my breasts are so dense that a mammogram is just like looking for a snowflake in a blizzard.  I need that breast MRI for comfort.  Initial PET and CT scans were negative.  Thank you for all your support on this web site. Emotionally, I am still working on, but much better.  I am taking Arimadex and Zometa IV every 6 mos. for prevention of reoccurance. Prayer helps!  Bonniee
Posts.Title: Update on My "Occult" Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I had a pretty radical lymph node dessection when they found the positive node.  They removed a very large portion of my underarm, (I didn't know I had that much there).  When they do this much surgery, nerves can be damaged.  I have never heard of this happening to anyone else, so I don't think you should worry about it.  Just go day to day, hour to hour, minute to minute, if needed, but get through it.  Hold the Lords hand. He is there for you. There is life on the other side of breast cancer!   Blessings and Prayers to you!  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Update on My "Occult" Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Your welcome.  You are entitled to have bad days.  Don't ever feel that you are a bother.  Please approach that woman at church.  She needs you too. There is a great sisterhood out there.  We need to be there for each other. Please don't hesitate if you have any more questions or concerns.  I am here for you.  Prayer partners are fantastic.  Blessings,   Bonnie
Posts.Title: Update on My "Occult" Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Amen sister!
Posts.Title: What do you think? Please Help

Posts.Content: Hi CindyOR, So sorry you had to join the ranks of us.  I had stage 2B breast cancer 10 year ago.  No tumor, but found in 3 lymph nodes.  I would get another opinion from another oncolgist, (perfer breast specialist- oncologist).  I had the nodes under my arm stripped out with the surrounding tissue, five months of chemo with Paxal and Taxal.  6.3 weeks of chest wall, full breast, superclavicular, and axillia radiation.  Let the experts give you the statistics and their recommendations, then you decide.  Good Luck and Blessings.  You will survive this!  That's the good news!  <3 Bonnie
Posts.Title: Radiation and chemo amounts

Posts.Content: Dear jgreen4, You sure have had your share of bouts with cancer!  Bless your heart!  It's been 7 years since my breast cancer, which was found, already in my lymph nodes, even after I was checked every 6 months.  I thought, how could this happen?  Right?  I am sure you are thinking how can this keep happening.  I was at a lecture by Dr. Susan Love, in Anaheim a few years ago and she said something so profound it always stuck with me, and it changed my life.  She said, "If cancer grows in your garden, you need to change the plants."  That hit me.  So, I completely changed my diet.  I am mainly plant based - no processed foods.  No dairy, only organic meats with no hormones.  And way less meat.  More than 5 ingredients,  It is processed.  Less is better.  I also learned the exercise changes the chemical structure of our bodies.  I am not as good about this, I will admit, but I try and walk 10,000 steps a day.  These things may "turn on, or off" the gene expression for cancer.  I read forward and heard the great news that it turned out not to be cancer and that is FANTASTIC!  I still would be careful.  Protect your body!  You have a long good life ahead!  Blessings, Bonniee
Posts.Title: when do you just stop treatment

Posts.Content: Dear jgreen4, You sure have had your share of bouts with cancer!  Bless your heart!  It's been 7 years since my breast cancer, which was found, already in my lymph nodes, even after I was checked every 6 months.  I thought, how could this happen?  Right?  I am sure you are thinking how can this keep happening.  I was at a lecture by Dr. Susan Love, in Anaheim a few years ago and she said something so profound it always stuck with me, and it changed my life.  She said, "If cancer grows in your garden, you need to change the plants."  That hit me.  So, I completely changed my diet.  I am mainly plant based - no processed foods.  No dairy, only organic meats with no hormones.  And way less meat.  More than 5 ingredients,  It is processed.  Less is better.  I also learned the exercise changes the chemical structure of our bodies.  I am not as good about this, I will admit, but I try and walk 10,000 steps a day.  These things may "turn on, or off" the gene expression for cancer.  I read forward and heard the great news that it turned out not to be cancer and that is FANTASTIC!  I still would be careful.  Protect your body!  You have a long good life ahead!  Blessings, Bonniee
Posts.Title: when do you just stop treatment

Posts.Content: So very sorry for the "bad genes."  I hear you.  I had a brother in law that did everything right too.  A skinny runner, health foods, never any alcohol or smoking and he had esphogeal cancer and died at 43.  I do have a cousin who had breast cancer at 40 and she is alive and well today at 75.   I am so happy for you that it turned out well for you and may you go on and have a healthy life.  I have one friend who had it four times and is still going!  It's so individual.  That's what makes it so fightening! Blessings for your continued health!
Posts.Title: when do you just stop treatment

Posts.Content: Breath, Breath and Breath. I hope by now you got good news. After diagnosis, there is no real way to feel totally "normal" again. I learn that we create our own "normal" - after cancer. You are in my prayers. Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: What do you think?

Posts.Content: So very sorry for the "bad genes."  I hear you.  I had a brother in law that did everything right too.  A skinny runner, health foods, never any alcohol or smoking and he had esphogeal cancer and died at 43.  I do have a cousin who had breast cancer at 40 and she is alive and well today at 75.   I am so happy for you that it turned out well for you and may you go on and have a healthy life.  I have one friend who had it four times and is still going!  It's so individual.  That's what makes it so fightening! Blessings for your continued health!
Posts.Title: when do you just stop treatment

Posts.Content: I am so happy for you! I had 3 positive nodes - consistent with infiltrating ductal breast cancer and no detectable cancer of the breast - very rare. I did 5 months of chemo and now I am starting radiation. They said no further surgery is needed because there is not a detectable cancer. Strange huh? Life is strange. I started Arimadex a month ago and have had some hot flashes, not bad. Otherwise I am doing fine on it. I have learned to just take the #### drugs and not read too much into the side effects. I tend to freak out! Chemo REALLY freaked me out! Good luck to you. I love this site too! Blessings to you, Bonnie
Posts.Title: What do you think?

Posts.Content: I still have numb feet almost 2.5 years post Chemo.  They say "It takes a long long time"  But no one says when or if it will ever go away.  Blessings,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Nerve damage from Chemo

Posts.Content: One of my friends said it took two months after her chemo to get her energy level back up again. She had to walk with a cane and use the little "motorized shopping carts" at the store. Her energy came back. Hang in there! Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: no energy months after chemo

Posts.Content: I have been diagnosed with Axillary Breast Cancer. No cancer in the breast can be found, only 3 lymph nodes postive for adenocarcinoma by axilllary node disection last week. They want to do chemo only, no radiation or mastectomy. They say it is systemic and not in the breast anymore, or maybe never was. Has anyone faced this type of cancer before? I am told because it is so rare, no good studies exist. I am scheduled for more opinions, but want to know if anyone here has had this experinence. Would appreciate any help. Thank you and Blessing to you all, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Axilllary Node Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I would check with an oncology pharmacist. They are usually the ones that prepare the chemo for infusion, so call your chemo clinic. Take Good Care, Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Arimidex and fish oil taking together

Posts.Content: I am an 8 year surviver.  If I were in your situation I would insist on a breast MRI.  Good luck.  Blessings,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Negative mammogram and ultrasound - what's next?

Posts.Content: I will just share my experience and you can take what you want from it.  I am sorry your doctors aren't more aggressive in finding out what is wrong with you.  If you have a teaching hospital or large medical center near you, I would go see one of the doctors that are on staff there.  Eight years ago I had one enlarged node under my left arm, showed up during a mammogram, (digital) - I went outside my health plan and paid cash, as my health plan did not offer digital.  Needle aspriation was inconclusive and core biopsy showed cancer.  Nothing in my breasts, just under my arm.  So I had a radical axilliary node disection, chemo and radiation.  No lump, no symtoms.  Nothing.  Felt fine.  No one could ever feel the enlarged node.  The surgery showed three cancerous nodes.  But here I am 8 years later.  But I am kind of a squeaky wheel, and fight for my life.  Which worked.  I wish you well.  Love and Blessings,  Bonnie
Posts.Title: Enlarged lymph nodes in breast and under arm

Posts.Content: Dear Patti, I am so sorry to hear of your sister's diagnosis. I think the answer is that no one knows for sure. We have all heard stories of people going on long after the doctors predicted. Everyone is an individual with different body chemistry and the body is an amazing thing! I worked with a woman who was given a very short time and she lived years after their prediction. You never know. We all never know. Enjoy each minute of every day with her. I will pray for her and you. Gods Blessings, Bonnie
Posts.Title: Looking for answers in all the wrong places.....
